description.narrative: In its draft strategic plan for the period 2020-2023, the organisation has identified four global outcome areas, with outcomes linked to each area: 1. Creating new spaces for literature, language, debate, dialogue, ideas and opinions. 1.1 Increase in inclusive spaces for diverse literature, language, opinions and dialogue to flourish, enhancing freedom of expression policy and practice. 1.2 Increased number of platforms for marginalized language writers. 1.3 Strengthen communication strategies and resources to share and showcase Centres’ work. 2. Improving the situation of writers at risk who are imprisoned or otherwise persecuted. 2.1 The situation of writers at risk is improved by PEN’s direct assistance, solidarity, advocacy and campaigning. 2.2 Displaced writers are given a platform and connected with professional networks, allowing them to continue with their work. 2.3 The voices of displaced writers are heard in global migration debates. 3. Influencing structural threats and barriers to freedom of expression 3.1 Contribute to ongoing societal debates on PEN's core thematic areas (hate speech, linguistic rights, gender equality) to counteract negative impacts. 3.2 Writers have resources and network required to support them in tackling PEN's thematic areas. 3.3 Duty bearers are receptive to PEN's demands for improvements to FOE policy and practice. 4. Strengthening the institutional capacity and sustainability of PEN, so that the movement is fully representative and relevant. 4.1 Increased capacity of the board to provide leadership & insight to PI. 4.2 Increased capacity of the committees to provide direction and expertise to PI and membership. 4.3 Increased capacity of Secretariat staff to deliver and develop strategic plan 2020-23. 4.4 Centres have increased capacity to be strong civil society actors and advocates for freedom of expression. The organisation has also developed a basic Theory of Change Model, which is basically showing the need for working within the four different domains in parallell in order to achieve the overall goal. In addition to the four domains of change, the strategic plan also outlines three thematic focus areas for the period: - Promoting free expression particularly for women and minority groups. - Countering hate speech and legal barriers to expression. - Promote translation and linguistic rights.

Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till organisationen PEN International om totalt 36 MSEK under en fyraårsperiod 2020-2023. För denna period har PEN utvecklat en strategi, med fokus på fyra tematiska områden:
1) Skapa nya utrymmen för litteratur, språk, debatt, dialog, idéer och åsikter. 2) Förbättra situationen för utsatta skribenter på flykt, som är fängslade eller på annat sätt förföljda. 3) Påverka strukturella hot och barriärer mot yttrandefrihet. 4) Stärka den institutionella kapaciteten och hållbarheten hos PEN som organisation.
Total budget för perioden är cirka 94 MSEK. Sidas stöd uppgår till 36 MSEK.

PEN International is a global network consisting of more than 20 000 writers, affiliated with over 150 federated centres in more than 100 countries. The overall goal of the organisation is to promote and defend freedom of expression, literatures, linguistic diversity and mutual respect and tolerace across borders.
PEN:s strategic plan for 2020-2023 has four thematic domains: 1) Creating new spaces for literature, language, debate, dialogue ideas and opinions. 2) Improving the situation of writers at risk who are displaced, imprisoned or otherwise persecuted. 3) Addressing structural threats and barriers to freedom of expression. 4) Strengthening the institutional capacity and sustainability of PEN, so that the movement is fully representative and relevant.
The total budget for the four-year period is around 94 MSEK. Sidas contribution for this period amounts to 36 MSEK.

description.narrative: - Objective 1, creating new spaces for literature, debate, dialogue idea and opinions It is noted that the covid pandemic made PEN implement some fundamental changes in moving almost all activities online. This has been a challenge for the organisation but also a great learning opportunity. As a result, 25 PEN centers from the global south received small grants to develop their online presence. PEN also hired digital consultants to support PEN centers. The learning reports mentions several cases where PEN centers have benefited from the support and managed to create a lively online presence and advocacy, but it also lifts up cases where this has been difficult and not successful. On many centers, the average age of the members is rather high and not everyone has adapted the new digital ways. Over all, the digitalisation of PEN's work is assessed as a very much needed development. - Objective 2, improving the situation of writers at risk who are displaced, imprisoned or otherwise persecuted The Freedom of expression and PEN's work have been deeply affected by the pandemic. Writers who were already harassed and persecuted have been even more so if commenting on the virus. The virus impact on writers in prison and their families have been devastating, both in terms of illness and death and in families denied access to their loved ones. During the first six months of 2020, there was a dramatic drop in the applications from ICORN. But during the last six months there was a just as dramatic rise, with 115 applications sent to PEN and 110 assessed and returned (compared to 2019 with 119). Sida notes that this work is highly valued by ICORN, and that there may be need for a dialogue to strengthen the capacity of PEN to In the activities for campaigning, the case list is impressive. Many "emblematic cases" in Zimbabwe, Uganda, Mexico, Myanmar, Egypt and Iran have made an impact on the international society, just to mention a few examples. In many of the contexts that have been in news focus during the year, such as Myanmar or Belarus, the writers active in the local PEN chapter have been important voices. - Objective 3. Addressing structural threats and barriers to freedom of expression During the covid pandemic PEN has advocated to address cases when emergency laws have been used to shut down criticism, for example in Thailand, Cambodia, Myanmar and Philippines. They have also debated "fake news" and how to combat disinformation. PEN has worked on restrictive laws in countries as Zimbabwe, Sierra Leone, Honduras, Nicaragua and Cuba. In Nicaragua the situation has grown severe, and the local PEN chapter has been forced to close down. China has continued to be a priority. PEN has also continued its work at EU level. - Objective 4. Strengthening the institutional capacity and sustainability of PEN PEN has developed a series of ten capacity building webinars, with 45 PEN members participating from Africa, Latin America and AsiaPEN held its 86th Annual Congress, the first ever entirely digital. The theme was "Freedom of Expression in the time of the Pandemic", and gathered participants from 90 PEN centers. The assembly adopted a resolution calling for public access to sound medical and scientific information about the virus, and for the global emergency not to be used by governments to silence voices of opposition. The first indigenous language center was also welcomed 2020 - PEN Chiapas Multicultural.
